content:
In the context of quasicategories, a natural transformation between functors F,G:C→DF,G:C\to DF,G:C→D is a map η:C×Δ1→D\eta:C\times \Delta^1\to Dη:C×Δ1→D such that η(X,0)=FX\eta(X,0) = FXη(X,0)=FX and η(X,1)=GX\eta(X,1) = GXη(X,1)=GX for any X∈CX\in CX∈C. This makes sense. I'm trying to get the meaning of naturality in this context.

Denote the unique 1-simplex in Δ1\Delta^1Δ1 by φ\varphiφ. Given an object X∈CX\in CX∈C, I believe the right definition for the natural morphism ηX:FX→GX\eta_X :FX\to GXηX​:FX→GX is

ηX:=η(s0(X),φ),\eta_X := \eta(s_0(X),\varphi),ηX​:=η(s0​(X),φ),

because we can calculate that d1(ηX)=FXd_1(\eta_X) = FXd1​(ηX​)=FX and d0(ηX)=GXd_0(\eta_X) = GXd0​(ηX​)=GX.

Now I really expected that, at least when XXX is an object of CCC, we'd have a square
image.png

That is, for any morphism f:X→Yf:X\to Yf:X→Y in CCC there are 2-simplices σ\sigmaσ and τ\tauτ, witnessing the compositions ηY∘Ff\eta_Y\circ FfηY​∘Ff and Gf∘ηXGf\circ \eta_XGf∘ηX​, such that d2(σ)=d2(τ)d_2(\sigma) = d_2(\tau)d2​(σ)=d2​(τ). However I really stuck here.

This is really a question about the universal case, that is, what are the 2-simplices σ\sigmaσ and τ\tauτ in the square Δ1×Δ1\Delta^1 \times \Delta^1Δ1×Δ1? (Here the first Δ1\Delta^1Δ1 corresponds to the morphism f:Δ1→Cf : \Delta^1 \to Cf:Δ1→C.) You have them drawn already in your diagram.
I think it should be d1(σ)=d1(τ)d_1(\sigma) = d_1(\tau)d1​(σ)=d1​(τ), by the way.

You can write down the maps σ,τ:Δ2→Δ1×Δ1\sigma, \tau : \Delta^2 \to \Delta^1 \times \Delta^1σ,τ:Δ2→Δ1×Δ1 in terms of degeneracy maps and then check everything algebraically using the simplicial relations, though I think it won't be very enlightening (except to verify that the formalism works as intended).
Reid, I understand you're saying that the natural squares come from applying η\etaη to the square Δ1×Δ1→(f,id)C×Δ1\Delta^1\times \Delta^1\xrightarrow{(f,\text{id})} C\times \Delta^1Δ1×Δ1(f,id)​C×Δ1?
Right, and then composing with η\etaη
Δ1×Δ1\Delta^1 \times \Delta^1Δ1×Δ1 has various nondegenerate simplices: the four vertices, the four "edges" of the square plus the diagonal, and two 2-simplices
The images of these simplices in DDD will be the various components of your diagram (FXFXFX, GXGXGX, ηX\eta_XηX​, etc.)
great, thanks! checking that the boundary is correct should be easy from here
